Well done to the French National Assembly üëè Here's some fun (quite sickening!) facts on (the) fast(est) fashion: Shein drops around 10,000 new items on its website daily. It produces a few hundred of these styles and makes more IF people start to buy them. (So at a bare minimum this is 1 million pieces of clothing PER DAY.) At any one time, they have around 500,000 styles on their website. Calculate this into a year and you are looking at 356, 000, 000 pieces of clothing (at a minimum) from one brand each year in the world. The quality might ensure a couple of wears (if any! You've seen the hauls, right?), then it's binned. Here's a little more ... the manufacturer's rapid use of virgin polyesters and huge consumption of oil churns out the same amount of C02 as around 180 coal-fired power plants. Feel ill about this yet?

France slows down fast fashion? Last Thursday, France's National Assembly (the lower house of the French Parliament) made history by pioneering the global fight against fast fashion. Implementing groundbreaking legislation, the new bill, which reins in the industry's rampant excess, imposes an environmental charge on low-cost items and bans fast fashion advertising, including social influencer ads. From 2025, France will be implementing a surcharge to help reduce the environmental impact of fast fashion. Each item will be subject to a ‚Ç¨5 fee, increasing to ‚Ç¨10 by 2030. This charge will be capped at 50% of the item's price tag. With this commitment, France will showcase that it is both fashionable AND sustainable. This bill is still to be greenlighted by a vote by the French Senate, allowing it to be published in a decree, but hopefully this is only as a matter of time. Where France leads the way, I wonder when the UK will follow... #fastfashion #sustainability #france
